Overall, the content does touch on related areas but lacks a primary focus and depth in the context of the Capability classification.

At no point does it directly reference Service Level Expectation (SLE) or discuss related core concepts such as forecasting work item completion times, SLE calculation, or continuous improvement based on SLE metrics. There is no language referencing historical cycle time data, probabilities, or explicit transparency around delivery timelines. The content focuses instead on organizational change, learning Scrum basics, and the emotional/structural benefits of the course. While the audience is broadly similar (Scrum/Agile practitioners), none of the main themes or details touch on SLE in any recognized form. Thus, scores are very low across all key dimensions; only a minimal score is given for faint conceptual overlap in the context of continuous improvement and transparency, which are generalized agile themes but not discussed through the SLE lens. No penalties are needed, as there are no outdated/contradictory references.
